comments.text:
I never did anything "GREAT" but I have been thru hell so many times...

I was 19 y/o when we (USMC) were gathered up and trucked down south to Kadena AFB where we waited on transport aircraft for hours.... We watched an SR71 Blackbird takeoff, and and hour or so later land. Every one of knew what was going on; Vietnam was falling, and we were awaiting the film development before we got orders for the flight. I knew that the next couple of hours would be the last "quiet time" we would experience until the mission was complete. That intense feeling came over everyone, and you no one was speaking. Then the roll began to the runway... and hell opened it's mouth to devour us all.

this made me THINK OF MY GRANDPARENTS! WHAT THEY WENT THRU WAY BACK in the 1920',s and 1930s! was recalling immediately my Grandma had told me as a teenager what she went thru, she had many miscarriages and stillbirths before she ever had my dad- the first son of three- what became the reason that I am here, wow imagine her looking at me at age 14 in the then 1984! era of such modern conveniences as she was telling me how awful a time it was for her and grandpa when they were going thru like 8! times before they finally got a live ,growing family,meanwhile she was barely noticed for it but I think back that I surely knew she was tightening up in the throat- I could barely tell, but she managed to stifle her tears!
and she had the strength to go straight thru telling me about it, and Im sitting in the brand new modern brick house that they had built in mid 1970's right after they sold other house and went in this one after my UNCLE HAD COME BACK FROM VIETNAM üòÑüíúüíúüíúüíúüíúüíØ as a well decoriated honored hero after at 17 shed put him in Catholic boarding school where he met my aunt, and he had been a mess in high school, GOT DRAFTED AT 17 AND they took them all and shaved heads, sent to bootcamp, he was drafted at 17 into the USMC! A MARINE! LOOKED SO GOOD IN HIS Picture smiling so awesome in his USMarine Corp. Uniform, unforgettable image in my mind- that pic always on the tv next my Granpa in his day as the cook on board USNAVY! WW2 AND in the US Army! I think in WW1- do I have this right?- I have to check on, he coulda been in Korean War ,?
and to think how STRONG Grandma was - as my uncle died of a long battle - cancer in 2002, I flew all the way back to small town for the funeral, my first time seeing what a USMC VFW service is like!
I stood there and stifled the deep uncontrollable sobbing as rivers flowed out my eyes, hiding under the tilted brim of my hat, thank God Id worn that!
And look over at my Grandma (Grandpa passed of cancer in 1988, and SHE is just calm as she can be, was saying later how RELIEVED AND GLAD FOR HER YOUNGEST SON THAT HE WAS DONE SUFFERING AND REST NOW IN PEACE!
SHE LOOKED SO RELIEVED AND PEACEFUL but quietly sat in her classic rocking chair rocking as always did, patting the cat on her lap as she quietly looked out the window that sunny,hot ,southern afternoon....never saw her cry.
I was sitting at the long NOW SO EMPTY, QUIET shiny,polished big family dining table, HEARING NOTHING BUT THE CLOCK'S TICKING not really that loud but unforgettable!
I sat quietly watching her from dining room ,with the triangular folded US Flag sitting on that polished shiny table with flowers and a big thing filled with plastic banannas and fake grapes,oranges,!
So very quiet there...I still sat with my very NYC looking black suit and skirt, big silk scarf still in place tied in the very same way for years on now in my 30s Id done like my life depends on - so exact and the brimmed sun hat still in same position on my head....finally stopped sweating under all that, you gotta have air conditioning back there so humid in summer!
And there's when it really SUNK IN HOW STRONG MY GRANDMA, AND GRANDPA HAD BEEN always!
and how much I never realized HOW Im more like MY DAD - their first EVER kid! (the tear flow at such times only ones to cry first and bigtime in such moments,- never them in sight of anyone!!)
and always wondered what made my grandmas eyes roll at my Dad, I mean I NEVER IMAGINED UNTIL THAT FUNETAL DAY OF UNCLE- in MY 30s- JUST EXACTLY WHO AND WHAT ELSE MY GRANDPARENTS WERE- THAT I DIDNT EVER REALIZE BEFORE!!
MY DAD'S MOM AND DAD! RIGHT? BUT NOT EVER IN SUCH ACTUAL REALUZATION! MAN THEY WERE SO AWESOME!
EVERYONE SHOULD HAVE GRANDPARENTS IN THEIR LIFE!

I want to know if its weird that I feel less important, more expendable as a human being because I've had a normal life with no death or grief.

I don't WANT grief. I don't WANT tragedy. I want to be strong though, I want to be someone to look up to. But my cushy life makes me lazy and unmotivated. I've tried to be enthusiastic about ANYTHING at all. Nothing works, I always go back to what I always was. Just a waste of space.

My family loves me and I have a couple dependable friends, but if I were gone nothing would really change. One thing I want to do is to start a family though, that would make life meaningful I think. But until then, I'll just be here, going through the motions, working, studying, doing what everyone else does. Some days I hate myself so much I can't imagine hating anyone else more, not even my enemies. I wish I had a complex life but I'm also relieved I don't.

comments.author: @the_original_Bilb_Ono
comments.text: Eh... This is true to a certain extent but it's not set in stone. There are people who after going through traumatic events, especially long term horror, they are broken and are never a fully functional adult. There are people who go through hell and come out not "all there". sure they may be "tough" in a certain sense but they aren't always these type of guys who go tackling the world head on, exploring, climbing mountains, exercising, running marathons, or whatever. Very often people who've been seriously traumatized become withdrawn, depressed, they don't trust people, they're super cautious about the smallest things... Seriously this misinformation that hard times creates a stronger man is very infuriating. It's simply not true at all. There are plenty of tough guys who had a great life, and there are plenty of broken men who can't stand up for themselves due to horrific trauma that was put on them. We don't use blanket ideas like that for something so complex as how the human brain and "soul" reacts to severe trauma.

comments.author: @SeanSchwifty
comments.text:
This phenomenon is often attributed to the concept of adversity fostering resilience and growth, known as post-traumatic growth or stress-induced growth. When individuals face significant challenges or hardships, they are forced to adapt and develop new skills or ways of thinking. Here are a few reasons why this may happen:

1. Building Resilience: Overcoming difficulties can help individuals develop resilience, the ability to bounce back from adversity. Each challenge provides an opportunity to strengthen this trait.
2. Problem-solving skills: Difficult situations often require unique or out-of-the-box solutions. People who have faced such situations may develop superior problem-solving abilities as they‚Äôve had to strategize and navigate their way through challenging circumstances.
3. Empathy and Understanding: Those who have experienced hardship may have a heightened ability to understand and empathize with others who are struggling, which can make them more compassionate leaders or team members.
4. Motivation: Sometimes, adverse experiences can serve as motivation. The desire to overcome a difficult past can drive individuals to achieve at high levels.
5. Perspective: Tough experiences often provide a broader perspective on life, which can lead to greater introspection, understanding, and sometimes, intelligence.

However, it‚Äôs important to remember that hardship isn‚Äôt a prerequisite for becoming exceptionally intelligent or mentally strong. There are plenty of people who achieve great things without having faced major adversity. It‚Äôs also worth noting that extreme adversity can also have detrimental effects if adequate support and coping mechanisms aren‚Äôt in place.

Ad astra per aspera ‚ú®
